segments.text: Rodriguez on December 6, 1989, at 308 McCullough, the residence of Mr. Rodriguez, concerning his life here in Bryan, Texas, and his tenure at Texas A&M University.
Mr. Rodriguez, in the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes.
This is a future historians, students, and researchers also can listen to it
And so you are free to use the interviewee's statements.
To begin, I'd like you to relay some biographical information to me, date of birth, your family history in Bryan, and the like.
Well, as you mentioned, my name is Pete L. Rodriguez.
I was born in Bryan, Texas in 1915.
My father, Manuel Rodriguez, was born in Zacatecas, Mexico in 1869.
He arrived in the United States in 1889, arrived here in Bryan same year.
My mother's maiden name was Clotilde Gondina.
She was born in Pearsall, Texas in 1880.
Her mother was born in Senton, Texas in 1835.
That makes her a native Texan.
It sure does.
Back when I was a child, I remember my daddy's restaurant.
It was a combination of a restaurant and saloon business.
It was in downtown Bryan.
The only part I can remember of that operation is when Dad was closing it up.
I was about three and a half years old.
And it was closed because of prohibition.
Yeah, about that time.
After that, Dad went to work in Goose Creek.
as an old Derek hand, I guess.
But according to Mom, he never left Bryan.
He commuted weekly.
So I got to see him at least once a week for many years after that, because Daddy did work for about 10 years.
I started school when I was seven years old.
In those days, we did not have ghettos here in Bryan.
at least not to the extent that it affected the Hispanics.
There were only a few Hispanic families in Bryan when I was growing up.
Would you describe the Hispanic community in Bryan as it was when you were growing up?
Basically, what was its relation to the rest of the community?
How many families were there, et cetera?
Well, we grew up with the rest of the community, which consisted of
I guess Italian people, Polish people, Czechoslovakians, and I guess other nationalities.
And we were accepted as equals by them.
You didn't feel any tension?
None whatsoever.
I don't know why, because later on there was tension, but at that time, back when I was growing up, there was no tension whatsoever.
None those early years, anyway.
At this time, I guess along the same lines, how did Brian treat his Hispanic citizens?
In your mind, I guess you've already answered part of this, but was there any legal, public, or hidden discrimination, or even just an air of bad feelings or anything like that?
I wish I could answer that, but I can't because I don't know what was in their mind, but they treated me well.
But I did notice some discrimination later on in the, I'd say, latter 30s.
I think this change of attitude took place
when a large influx of Hispanic began moving into Bryan during the late 30s, as I mentioned before, from nearby towns such as Cameron, Hearn, Caldwell, Somerville, Rockdale, and so forth.
And I believe this is when the school board decided to segregate the school.
I never did understand why.
A school strictly for Hispanic was established in North Bryan near the San Jacinto Loop.
It was known then as the Ibarra School, named after a Mexican Baptist church minister.
Regardless of what part of Bryan an Hispanic lived, his children had to attend that school.
The end result was that the students did not learn much due to inadequate facilities, and they were inadequate,
and extra large classes per teacher.
Can you elaborate a little bit on how they were inadequate?
Was there just not enough?
Were they not using proper text?
Were the classes just spread out amongst the grades so much?
Actually, the rooms were crowded with students.
They only had one blackboard, and it wasn't wide enough to cover from one end to the room to the other.
And a teacher somehow or other seemed to want
squeeze the material that we think the kids had to learn in that small blackboard.
And I remember I went to see this because I had my son there.
And I told his teacher, I said, you need additional blackboard so that the kids can go up there and write because they can't do this because it's covered with your material and things such as that.
So were these white teachers?
Yeah, they were all white teachers.
Yeah, they were white teachers.
But they were kind.
They appeared to be kind.
I think they were doing the best they could under the circumstances.
But I could tell that they didn't care about being there.
I think that they felt that they were recognized as inferior teachers by the fact of being sent over to the Yvonne School.
You didn't grow up in this system.
You went to Bryan High School.
That's right.
Can you contrast how you think you were educated to this?
In those schools, there was a lot of room.
It was not crowded.
You had blackboards all around the room when the teacher would tell us
We've got a problem.
I want all of you to go to the black room, the blackboard.
We'd all go to the blackboard and we'd do whatever she wanted us to do.
And not only that, we'd have different teachers for different subjects.
While here at the Morrow School, that one teacher taught every subject.
She taught arithmetic, spelling, and geography, and history, and everything else.
And you know yourself that she probably was good in one area, but not that good in the rest of them.
And I know this, you could see this, because this later was reflected in the students when they attended high school.
They all flunked.
I mean, they never finished high school.
So after like nine years of bar schooling, it went on.
That's right.
And they felt inferior.
The kids did.
They felt that they were not wanted.
And they did not feel equal to the other kids there when they got to high school or when they were in high school.
They would hang around with themselves, with the rest of the Hispanics.
And they'd play with each other.
They would not play with the Anglos.
I guess they felt that they weren't wanted.
And so, as a consequence, they just didn't do well.
And they just dropped out.
What about the language, too?
That's another thing.
They never learned the English language well.
They needed to mingle with Anglo kids.
So be immersed in it.
That's right.
And they did not do that.
They just mingled with themselves.
And so when they were with themselves, they spoke nothing but Spanish.
Nothing wrong with that.
But still, they had to learn the English language.
I see.
Do you know how long the Bar School was operating?
I think the Bar School lasted about 10 years, approximately 10 years.
OK.
How did the Bryan public school system actually become desegregated, and how are you involved in this?
Well, you know, in 1939, World War II got started, and everything was focused towards the war.
I mean, somehow or other, people were excited, and war was the primary concern.
And the schools were not in the forefront like they are today.
They were thinking about war.
Of course, I went overseas, and a lot of the parents of these kids went overseas.
And we left things like they were in those schools.
But then when we came back, we found out what was happening to these kids.
You and some other veterans?
That's right, me and some other veterans.
Actually, I got it started.
Actually, I decided to get a group of people whose children were going to that school, and I know they didn't like it, and I asked them.
I had a meeting with them.
I don't know if they would go before the school board with me and complain about the school, and they say they were more than ready to go.
And so I went and met with one of the board members,
and told him what I had in mind.
He agreed it was all right for his concern.
What exactly did you have in mind?
Beg your pardon?
What exactly did you have in mind?
To get rid of the school, to desegregate the school, to permit these children to go to another school other than Ibarra, to get rid of Ibarra.
And so then I asked him if
to give me the names of the board members, because since I just got back from overseas, I didn't know the names of these board members.
And he did, and some of them I knew, and some of those board members, I knew them because I went to school with some of their children.
And so, actually, I knew Mr. Webb Howell, whose dad did business with him at one time or another.
And so he was the president and chairman of the board.
And I went to see him at his office.
And he said, definitely, I'll call a meeting for you.
So he gave us a meeting.
It was on a Tuesday night.
I think we met, if I'm not mistaken, at the old Bryan High School.
And we met there on the third floor.
And the superintendent was there.
I asked some of the members that went with me, some of these people that are going to help me try to get rid of the school.
I asked them questions to the president and the board members why they want to get rid of the school.
One of them would get up and say, well, my wife is taking my son all the way to Huntsville every morning.
Drop him off in the afternoon, go pick him up.
And then two others say, well, mine is going with another group to Navasota.
And we are doing the same thing.
And then I said, well, take me, for instance.
I've got my children, and they're consolidated.
And so NM Consolidated wasn't a problem.
Big part?
They were not.
No, they were not segregated.
Absolutely not.
And so they were, actually, they were surprised to hear this.
I don't think they were aware, Peter, that this was going on.

These sacrifices were being made by these parents to get a better education for their children by taking them out of town because they knew that they were not getting the kind of education that other kids were getting in the other schools here at Ibarra.
And so they were very receptive to what we had to say.
And Mr. Webb Howell thanked us for bringing this to his attention and to their attention.
And I think they all in unison said that we were going to get rid of that school immediately.
And sure enough, within two months, it was gone.
Two months?
Within two months, it was gone.
And so the kids were sent to these other schools, to go to the school of their choice.
And accommodations were made to accommodate them.
And they were very gladly accepted by the teachers.
The teachers seemed to be glad to have them there.
And so that ended that school.
It left the mark on these kids that attended Ibarra because they never did get rid of this feeling of inferiority that they developed by going there.
And they never did finish high school.
I'd say that 20% of the kids that went to Ibarra finished high school.
The rest of them did not.
And that was because of that school.
And I can see this today.
I can see a lot of my friends' children, a lot of my friends will complain about how this affects their children.
They say, my boy didn't go to college on account of that.
My boy didn't advance on account of that.
And I remember at one time I was talking to the principal of the boys' school, who was also principal of that school,
And he knew that I had went before the board, and he didn't like it.
And I told him, I said, look, these kids need a better education.
They want to advance you like all the other kids.
And the response he gave me was that, he said, someone has to take the ditches.
And of course, I didn't expect that from an educator, but that's what he said.
And I think, that's right, I remember that.
He told me that on the school ground.
But you can see why, from that attitude of this principal, why the school board didn't know that this school's having this effect on these kids.
And so I was very appreciative of the group that went with me, because they helped a lot.
And actually, they're ultimately responsible for getting rid of this segregated school.
Can you compare the Ibarra school
the treatment of Hispanics and education in Bryan public school system to that of blacks?
What do you know about the black education or community at this time?
Well, I don't know too much about black education.
The only thing I do know is that the blacks had black teachers, whereby the Hispanics had white teachers.
And the blacks
The schools were in their ghettos near them, and I guess it was convenient for them because it was there, it was close, it was nearby, but still it was a segregated school.
I never heard of a white going there to teach them or anything like that.

I know that, I know this to be a fact that at times when our school started, when school started, we were issued new books, all of us were issued new books, and the books that were used the previous year or were old, they put them all in boxes and they were taken over to the
Black schools.
So they never did get new books.
They only got old books.
They got books that we had already used up.
And they were always separate, is that right?
They were always separate, right.
They were always separate.
And they were just discriminated against.
And they were always segregated.
I don't know what else to say.
I mean, they had their own football stadium.
They played with each other.
They could not, actually, their high school football team could never play without a football team against ours.
Yet they had a big stadium over there.
And actually, sometimes they had more people going to their games than we had white people going to ours, because there are a lot of blacks here.
But it was, I mean, I enjoyed going to their games.
As long as you paid, you could go to their games.
But they couldn't go to our games.
Even if they paid, they couldn't go.
Some of them would mingle in and stand up by the fence and kind of sit there.
But that's the extent of their participation in our football.
But that's the way it was in those days.
What about publicly in Bryan?
They were disallowed from public facilities or had separate public facilities?
Your public places had separate facilities.
All your doctor's offices had separate facilities.
And the hospitals had separate facilities and separate rooms for blacks.
And you could notice that in the hospital, that all of the activity was on the end of the whites and hardly nothing on the end.
I remember when you were in Europe,
If your daddy was born, I could see a lot of activity there in the hospital.
But on the black side, there was only two rooms, I think.
It was kind of semi-dark and nothing going on.
Every now and then you'd see a nurse go in there and come back out.
There just wasn't any place where the blacks could sit.
They had to either wait on the outside or in the hallway right directly in front of the room where the patient was.
But we, on the white side, had seats and everything.
So they didn't have the conveniences that we did.
And I think that was, to me, it was unjustly.
Were the hospital facilities always open to Hispanics, too?
Yeah, always.
Definitely, yeah.
There was some sporadic discrimination.
I don't know.
They tell me that it came in the form of preference, in other words.
And I think that they would readily treat an Anglo quicker than they would an Hispanic.
And usually, because we only had two hospitals in Bryan, lots of time is overcrowded.
If an Hispanic would go sick and need a room, they'd make sure that the Anglos were taken care of first before the Hispanic.
They never told you this, and nobody knew it, not even the Anglos, but the Hispanic.
The Hispanic knew it because it affected them.
I know that.
It happened to the people that I know.
They could see an empty room when they were there, but then a little bit, it wasn't empty anymore, and the Spaniard, Angler was in there, or whatever.
And he would be sent back home and say, well, come back tomorrow, maybe we can get you in the hospital.
You know, that's the way it was.
We've already talked about public schools and Brian and how Hispanics fit in, what they had to do.
What about A&M?
What were the opportunities for Hispanic students at A&M?
And were there really any there from the community?
Well, actually, I think that A&M always had its doors open for, I say, Latin people.
I'm going to use that term right now, because there were a lot of Latin people, a lot of Latin students there from Mexico, from South America.
And there was some discrimination.
there, but not much.
I think it's mostly a language barrier because those people from Mexico, the students from Mexico could not communicate very well.
And so that's the only thing I could see is that they just could not communicate.
But I never did see why Latin from those foreign countries was mistreated.
And I don't recall that any Hispanics from this country were mistreated because there were hardly any.
I mean, between you and me, I just hardly ever saw Hispanics attended A&M.
Every now and then you'd see, excuse me, you'd see one or two or three.
And it may be, it might have been that A&M was not doing any recruiting at that time.
At that time, everybody had to join the Corps.
And a lot of people just did not want to go into the Corps, so they'd go to other schools.
And I think that's what kept a lot of the Hispanics out.
They would rather go to other schools, but they didn't have to join a military regiment of some sort.
And like I said, another thing, too, I don't think that
A&M had any recruiting system for recruiting Spanish because there was no need, I don't think, because actually, let me change that.
I think there was no prospects available because the Spanish were not finishing high school.
Most were dropouts because a lot of these schools were discriminated, in other words, segregated.
And so every now and then, I guess you'd get one or two, but that's it.
Even, I understand, in Houston, in the University of Houston, it wasn't the University of Houston then, they called it something else.
There were hardly any Hispanics either in these colleges.
But like now, now you see quite a few.
So I think that's what
kept, that's why, it's not that A&M discriminated against anybody, it's just that first, there were not enough high school graduates among the Hispanic people, among the Hispanic students.
And secondly, they didn't like the core aspect of it.
They didn't want that because in those days, you know, the way that freshman was treated,
you're lucky to come out alive.
And they could see a lot of that, and they didn't want to undergo that.
And they figured that if they do that to the Anglos, look what they do to the Hispanics.
Let me change a little bit and talk about civic and religious activities of the Hispanic community in Bryan.
And what role did the church play?
Are you talking about back then when I was growing up or now?
Back then.
Way back?
Well, actually, I was baptized in the Catholic church.
St. Joseph, and that's where we went to church because there weren't any Spanish-speaking churches around.
And are you asking what role did we play with the church or what role did the church play with us?
Give me a little of both.
Was there much interaction or did that come later?
The only thing I know is that the only special events that we attended was when there was a confirmation of some sort.
There was, say, a bazaar to raise benefits.
We'd go and participate.
and watch what was going on and buy a few things to help the church.
And then, of course, we'd go to church on Sunday.
And we were treated well.
I mean, of course, since I think that the time that we were going to church, only about two more Hispanic families were going.
And we were some sort of a novelty.
We attracted attention because we were a little different.
Hair was dark.
Our skin was a little darker.
But other than that, the priests were very friendly to us.
They were always real good to us.
And they'd come by.
Because in those days, sometimes the horse and buggy was late getting there to pick us up.
But if we needed to ride home, they'd take us home.
I said, no, we got a ride coming.
Sure enough, a little big cluck, cluck, cluck, there comes a buggy, and we go home.
A wagon or a Model T Ford, one or two.
They were nice.
Of course, mom and papa missed out a lot because they didn't understand too much.
Because if we'd go to St. Joseph's Church, it was preached lots of time in what you'd call Polish language or maybe Czechoslovakian language.
Or if you go to the Italian church, it was preached in Italian.
So we missed out.
So this is why I decided to go to the Baptist church for a while, where they spoke English and I could understand it.
And I enjoyed it.
But then later on,
The so-called Catholic Church got away from this speaking their own language because they saw that the kids were not benefiting.
The kids understood English better than they did their own language.
So then they started hiring priests that could speak both languages.
So they were kind of bilingual.
They'd speak Polish for the old Polish people, and they'd make a little English for the younger, and the Italian would do the same thing.
And that worked out pretty good.
Of course, to me, I think that the services were a little long, and I think that had a lot to do with it.
But now, at the present time, they've got priests that speak nothing but English in most churches now.
In our church, we have a bilingual priest that speaks, right now at the present time, that speaks English and Spanish.
And the reason he speaks Spanish, not for the people that live and were born here, but because we have so many
citizen newly arrivals from Mexico due to the amnesty program.
They're here, they don't understand, so he is also doing a little preaching in Spanish.
What about civic involvement at that time?
Was there much?
Not how far back you want to go, Peter.
As far as you can take me.
Well, when I was a young man, I was pretty involved in YMCA work.
and March of Dimes and let's see, quite a few other things.
I can't remember some of it, but oh yeah, go ahead.
I was also involved in Parent Teachers Association, which you know.
the first year when your daddy went to Ibarra.
I was a parent teacher there, but I didn't like it, but I was there anyway.
Well, Peter, we had a voice in the city.
We could do anything we wanted to, but it was up to us to participate.
What happened that so many of us spoke Spanish so much that we'd go to these meetings and we did not want to get involved because we felt that we couldn't communicate.
We felt that we couldn't cope with the English language.
And well, we were afraid of derision would amount to because of the language.
And some of that exists right now, spreading time.
Some of the young boys, I mean, some of these people don't want to talk.
They hold back because they're afraid that they can't communicate.
Yet, they speak perfect Spanish.
They speak well in Spanish.
But if we want to get involved, it was there.
They encouraged us to get involved.
And I know I was involved in quite a few things, numerous of them, way back there.
Actually I had a little combo myself that we played in high school.
And we played little high school dances.
I used to play the harmonica and the drums and another kid used to play the clarinet and another one played the guitar and I forget what.
But we made some noise.
And actually we got so good that we went and played for some of the civic organizations.
I guess they just wanted to do us a favor, you know, but it was all right.
But there weren't too many things that Bryan was doing those days other than YMCA and there was no boys club, you know, and there were no JC's.
The Chamber of Commerce was very small and it was, now that was a place where
We never participated because it was made up only of the so-called elite people, you know, people who ran the community.
And it was not inviting to working people, you know, blue collar people.
It was not inviting.
And so, however, now it is.
Now they want anybody, but not nowadays.
Can you tell me a little bit about Brian B's Recreational Club?
You mentioned the Boys Club earlier.
I know that this eventually more or less evolved into that.
Can you tell me why it was started and basically what it did?
Well, what it was, it was a group of boys that I started as a Cub Pack.
It was a Cub Pack group.
And there were kids.
Some of those kids actually were from broken homes.
I could name them if you wanted to, but I don't care for doing that.
And then they grew out of it.
And I was a cup pack assistant cup master.
I was just beginning myself.
And then later they grew into Boy Scouts.
And I've had them for a long time in Boy Scouts.
And they were good troops.
And I mean, we'd win all these prizes when we'd compete with other troops.
And then they outgrew that.
And then I didn't want these boys to disperse because where would they go?
So what I did, I decided to organize a baseball team.
And we organized a baseball team.
And there was a suggestion to the boys to come out with a name.
And some of them came up with different kind of names.
And they chose Bees because they had a reason for that.
I remember something like the Bees, by working together, would produce something worthwhile.
You know?
And because of that, we decided to play different teams from different places.
And there was a good baseball park here that at one time housed a professional baseball team in Bryant.
But they went broke, and then another team decided to move in.
They went broke, and so the park was just laying there.
I mean, it looked like a lake.
The fence had fallen.
The roof had caved in, and it was in bad shape.
So I told the kids that I would go see the owner, Mr. Travis Bryan.
see if he'd let us fix the park so we could play in it.
So I went to see him.
And he told me, he said, I'm not loaning any money on that park.
I said, well, I'm not asking for a loan.
What I want is just for you to give us an opportunity to put that park back like it was.
He said, well, that would entail a lot of money and a lot of sacrifice, a lot of work.
You can't do that.
I said, well, I will try.
He said, if you can do it, you go right ahead.
So we took it.
And sure enough, we did.
We made that park, put it back like it was brand new.
And that enabled a lot of other teams to play in it.
It enabled A&M Consolidated to play there.
A&M Consolidated had to call me to schedule the game.
And also Bryan High School enabled them.
It also enabled a black baseball team to play there, a black high school baseball team.
The American Legion.
and enable also the Bryan Air Force teams to play there.
Because at that time, we had the Air Force here.
And of course, we played there, the Bryan Bees.
And we were sponsoring two teams, the Bryan Bees, the Bryan Aztecs, and then later on, the Bryan Merchants.
We played there, and I scheduled all those games.
Shortly after that, I became a member of the Bryant Park Board.
And Mr. Carbosier was the chairman of the board.
No, he was not.
Someone else was.
Mrs. Culpepper, I think, was chairman of the board.
And I suggested to Mr. Carbosier that the city of Bryant should buy that park.
And so he said he thought that was a good idea.
And so we went to see Mr. Bryant.
We made a very good deal with it, good deal.
So then Mr. Carabasio went and made a motion to the park board, and we buy the park.
I second the motion.
And then it was sent to the city council, I don't know, the Brian commission, the Brian commission.
And they voted to buy the park.
And I named the park Travis.
I decided to give it a name, and I just thought I'd name it Travis.
I think it's called Travis today.
But as a result of that accomplishment on behalf of the Brian B's, we accommodated a lot of people, a lot of kids.
And they played that for years and for years.
Actually, it kept me busy at the office.
I was doing more work for that park than I was doing for my own job.
I was neglecting my own job and kind of that, but nobody there seemed to mind it.
What about the Boys Club?
And then, of course, actually, I also, because of that, somehow they approached me about organizing, help organize the, you should call it a league team.
And I was very instrumental in organizing, helping with that.
And then, of course, one of my members, Brian Bees, wanted to set it,
He said, you know, we're growing now.
We're going to leave this team.
We're going to break out.
What's after that?
And he suggested to me that he'd heard of Brian Boyd's club in different places.
And I didn't even know what a Brian Boyd's club was.
And he explained it to me.
And I thought it was a good idea.
So I told him, I said, do you know of anybody that you could contact that would, yeah, I know Mr. So-and-so.
So he, I can't remember this gentleman's name, a wonderful person because he came over and talked to me and talked to other people.
And then we decided to get together and we met in an old lumber yard in Bryan.
And actually, we even invited WT McDonald, who was the present judge at that time, district judge, 85th District Court judge.

And he got up and didn't discourage us, but in essence, he said that he didn't think people would buy anything like that here in Bryan, that people in Bryan would not support it because it's going to take money.
But anyway, we decided to go ahead and start one.
So at the second meeting, we got a charter group.
We named the charter members.
And Mrs. Parker, Marianne Parker, was at that time.
And we made her chairman of the charter.
because we figured we needed her influence in the community.
And we got started.
Then it was up to us to go out and recruit kids to come and join.
And we went out and recruited a bunch of kids.
And they started coming, and some people started donating basketballs and little pool tables.
And Mrs. Parker and I, we decided to ride for a boat
We went to the campus, and we got thrown out until we got off the campus.
We made a little money off that boat.
We were able to buy more supplies, and that's how we got started.
Not only Curtis Dickey, but Bernstein and others that played real well for Cheryl, made a name for themselves, they went through Boy's Club.
And we have a lot of kids that went through there that were from broken homes, and now today are successful people in the world.
And so I think that the Boys Club was a good thing for Brian.
And I want you to know that I don't want to take credit for all that because of starting it, but I was one of the members that started.
A lot of Hispanic kids go through there also?
A lot of Hispanic kids were going.
At that time, we were very much involved.
And we worked hard to get it going.
But the overall success of it, as it is today, belongs to the community of Bryan and to the United Fund who are now supporting it.
But that's how it got started.
It was bleak when we started.
And it looked like every year it got bleaker, but then we never gave up.
And we had criticism from people saying that we were accommodating kids that were not from good families.
But actually, that's the kind of kids we wanted.
Kids that had problems, kids from broken homes.
And we realized it was a challenge, but we had a lot of volunteers work with those kids.
And they turned out to be
good kids later on.
Kids that later on paid back some of the benefits that they derived from Boys Club by working in Boys Club voluntarily and helping other kids.
This was very obvious.
It's obvious right now.
So, these kids, Brian Bees, did well.
Boys Club was an aftermath of that.
I think what I've read earlier says that at least
Half of these people, or half of these boys involved in the Brian B's Club actually went to finish college.
Right, they did.
Actually, more than half of them went to finish college.
None of them dreamed that they would ever go to college.
This came about because of their athletic ability, their baseball playing.
I remember that when I went with them to Allen Academy and asked the director there,
that I would appreciate if you'd give them a trial to see if they'd get a scholarship.
And he said, well, we've given too many scholarships already.
I said, well, why don't you just give them a trial for maybe later on you may have scholarships.
Well, he said, he directed me to the coach, and the coach gave him a trial.
And sure enough, the coach took about eight of them right off the bat and gave him scholarships.
And for the first time in the history of Allen Academy,
They won a state junior college championship.
Without that group, they couldn't have done it because the coaches said it themselves.
And after that year, they had a big banquet for all those kids.
And then later on, more Bs went down and more Bs went down.
Actually, they wanted all our boys because we had them.
And I'll tell you another thing.
We had such a good team that in that year, I don't remember what year it was, A&M won the district.
Texas A&M?
Texas A&M, and they wanted to give us a practice game, and Bill Bell said, you can announce it like a real game because we're going to play.
I said, okay.
So we announced it, and we had a full stadium, and we beat them pretty bad.
I forget, I think at that time it was 3-2, and he felt real bad about it.
The following year, he won again the district.
The Southwest Conference?
Southwest Conference, yeah.
And so we beat him again.
And I think we shut him, I think 61 the second time.
That's how good our team was.
And that was made up of these kids that had this dream of playing baseball and improving themselves.
And today, a lot of them are successful boys.
Some are teaching school.
Some have got good business.
And about 20 years ago, we had a reunion that gave me a surprise party.
Had about 150 kids there.
But I mean, they were there.
And then about 10 years after that, they had another reunion.
So we still stay together.
We communicate, and they communicate with me.
